Package calculator

Class CalculatorAdvanced

java.lang.Object
calculator.Calculator
calculator.CalculatorAdvanced
public class CalculatorAdvanced extends calculator.Calculator
Class used to simulate simple calculator that allows exponentiation and factorial operations, Armstrong and Perfect number inquiry in addition to the four basic arithmetic operations inherited from the class Calculator.
Since:
2021-03-30
Version:
1.0.1
Author:
Aleksa Majkic

  • Method Details

    • calculateAdvanced

      public void calculateAdvanced(char action) throws calculator.exception.NumberNotInAreaException, calculator.exception.NotSupportedOperationException
      Method allows user to calculate the factorial for the floor value of the current calculator value or to calculate exponentiation of the current calculator value to the power of the number action that is in range [0, 9].
      Parameters:
      action - parameter used to determine which calculation is going to be conducted. If the value is '!' then the numbers factorial is going to be calculated; for this calculation the current calculator value has to be in range [0, 9] otherwise NumberNotInAreaException will be thrown. If the value is numerical character in the range [0, 9] then the exponentiation of the calculator value will be calculated and stored as a new value for the calculator. Other values will cause the method to throw an NotSupportedOperationException.
      Throws:
      calculator.exception.NumberNotInAreaException - when an action isn't a valid operator, '!' or a numerical charter in range [0, 9].
      calculator.exception.NotSupportedOperationException - when the operation is set on factorial but the internal value of the calculator is not in range [0, 9].

    • hasCharacteristic

      public Boolean hasCharacteristic(char value) throws calculator.exception.NumberNotInAreaException, calculator.exception.NotSupportedOperationException
      Method checks if the stored value inside of the calculator is Armstrong or Perfect number. For both calculations floor value of the calculator value has to be equal to or greater than 1, otherwise NumberNotInAreaException will be thrown.
      Parameters:
      value - is parameter used to distinguish between Armstrong or Perfect number check.
      Returns:
      true if the current calculator value has the requested property, otherwise false.
      Throws:
      calculator.exception.NumberNotInAreaException - when a floor value of Calculator.currentValue is smaller than 1
      calculator.exception.NotSupportedOperationException - when an unknown parameter value is used

    • perfectNumber

      private Boolean perfectNumber(int number)
      Helper method that checks if a number is perfect.
      Parameters:
      number - is a value for which the property perfect is checked.
      Returns:
      true if the number is perfect, otherwise false.

      private Boolean armstrongNumber(int number)

      Parameters:
      number - is a value for which the property Armstrong is checked.
      Returns:
      true if the number is Armstrong, otherwise false.

    • mathFloor

      private int mathFloor(double number)
      Helper method that takes as input a real number and gives as output the greatest integer less than or equal to number.
      Parameters:
      number - is the value whose floor value is calculated.
      Returns:
      greatest integer less than or equal to input number.

    • mathPower

      private int mathPower(int base, int exponent)
      Helper method that computes power of base to the exponent by Binary Decomposition of exponent.
      Parameters:
      base - is a number whose power is calculated.
      exponent - is a number that corresponds to the number of times the base is used as a factor.
      Returns:
      calculated power of a given base value.

    • factorial

      private int factorial(int number)
      Helper method that recursively calculates a factorial.
      Parameters:
      number - is a value whose factorial is calculated.
      Returns:
      factorial of the given number.
